At the end of each Cowboy Bebop, there is a phrase (or a title card, as the [Cowboy Bebop Wiki](http://cowboybebop.wikia.com/wiki/Memorable_Quotes_from_Cowboy_Bebop#Ending_Title_Cards_in_Order_of_Episodes) calls them). In most of the sessions, the phrase reads **"See You space cowboy..."**.  
However, there are some variations:  

- Session 3: **"Easy Come, Easy Go..."** - It is (most likely) a reference to how easy it is to win and lose money in a casino, since this episode takes place in one.  
- Session 11: **"The End"** - I actually don't know if this is a reference, or simply a classic *'The End'*.
- Session 12: **"To Be Continued "** - It simply states the fact that this episode is a *Part 1*, and the story is to be continued in the next session.  
- Session 13: **"Do You Have a comrade? "** - It is a reference to:  
>! the relationship that Gren had with Vicious, and the fact that Spike helps him in the end.  

- Session 15: **"Sleeping Beast"** - It is a reference to *Sleeping Beauty*, since:
>! Faye was 'asleep' too (preserved in a cryogenic state). But I am not sure about the *Beast* part.  

- Session 17: **"Life is but a dream..."** - Is a reference to the events that take place during the episode, namely
>! their hallucinations.  

- Session 22: **"See You Space Samurai... "** - It is a reference to
>! Andy's transformation (from cowboy to samurai) in the end of the episode.  

- Session 23: **_None_** - Don't know if this even needs to *have* a reason.

**How much of the original material is animated in first season of Maoyuu Maou Yuusha?**

Below are my research as I post this question.

---
According to [Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maoyu#Light_novels), the original light novel series has finished serialization in 2012 with 8 volumes in total:

> - 01 *“Become My property, Hero” “I Refuse!”* (「この我のものとなれ、勇者よ」「断る!」)
> - 02 *Conspiracy of Kurultai* (忽鄰塔（クリルタイ）の陰謀)
> - 03 *Expeditionary force of Seiken* (聖鍵（せいけん）遠征軍)
> - 04 *What Can be Done With These Hands* (この手でできること)
> - Episode 01 *Episode1 Female Magician from Elms country* (エピソード1 楡の国の女魔法使い)
> - 05 *The other side of the hill* (あの丘の向こうに)
> - Episode 00 *Episode0 Archer from Dune country* (エピソード0 砂丘の国の弓使い)
> - Episode 02 *Episode2 Female Knight from Flowers country* (エピソード2 花の国の女騎士)

The 3 "episodes" are likely side stories (or prequel?) to the main story. That makes the whole of main story contained within 5 volumes.

The last episode of the anime doesn't seem to suggest that the story has ended (rather, it seems to plant seeds for future events):

>! The Central Nation and the Church is going to start the third Holy Crusade, and it was revealed that the Central Nation and the Church has been working with one of the Demonic Clans to keep the war going.

---
>! Maou called for meeting of all Greater Races (クリルタイ), but how the meeting plays out is not mentioned. Knowing how the expectation of the Demonic Races and Maou's philosophy to be mismatched, we can assume that the meeting has not taken place.

**"クリルタイ"** is mentioned in the last episode, which is part of the title of volume 2 of light novel series (忽鄰塔（**クリルタイ**）の陰謀). This seems to suggest that the 12 anime episodes only uses up 1 volume worth (!) of the light novel series.

Was the ending of Mawaru Penguindrum completely incoherent?

The ending of Mawaru Penguindrum had a lot of ambiguous symbolism.

My first impression was that the writer had no idea how to resolve the fundamental questions of the plot, and thus had to throw out completely unresolvable symbolism in order to fake an ending.

A few of my driving questions throughout the series were as follows:

1 - The recurring theme of the show is that the main character would get possessed by a penguin hat, and pull one or two characters into a kind of alternate reality where they were handcuffed.  To what degree was this a hallucination?  To what degree does the show actually explain the penguin hat's power?

2 - Penguins 1, 2, and 3, plus the additional penguin, were important characters who were not visible to most people in the show.  To what degree were they hallucinations, and to what degree were they paranormal?  

3 - At various points, the characters believed that there were supernatural powers at work. Were there any supernatural phenomena within the show, or were the characters entirely deluded about this?

a - To what degree were supernatural factors involved in prolonging the main character's life despite her fatal illness?

b - How effective were Ringo's attempts at spell-casting?

4 - At least one of the characters suffered persistent delusions and hallucinations for the first half of the show. (For example, one boy believed he was meeting contacts in a well-maintained restaurant, when in fact he was hallucinating in a broken-down ruin.) How many characters were hallucinating?  

5 - Were there any forces in the story that were godlike, in that they were both powerful and capable of passing judgement on mortals?  In particular, at the end of the show, it seems that two boys sacrificed their mortal lives for the sake of two girls.  Was this a sacrifice made to a god or other cosmic power?

***Humanity Has Declined*** (人類は衰退しました *Jinrui wa Suitai Shimashita*), or ***Jintai*** (人退?) for short is a Light Novel Series written by Romeo Tanaka in 2007. Artwork was originally done by Tōru Yamasaki in the first 6 volumes but in 2011 was replaced by Sunaho Tobe.

The story is set in a post-apocalyptic world where Humanity's numbers are declining while being replaced by the Fairies, small human like creature with permeate smiles, who are considered the New Humanity. the Fairies have incredibly advance technology which could be considered Magic and have a total disregard for human safety. they love sweets and more appear when they are having fun (thought to be how they reproduce)

The main protagonist is an unnamed female, either refered to as "I" (わたし *Watashi*), "Ms. Sweets" (お菓子ちゃん *Okashi-chan*) or by her title as Mediator. As her title describes she is the mediator between Humans and Fairies.

In March 2010 a  the first chapter of a Manga adaptation of the Light Novel illustrated by Rei Neyuki was released in that month's issue of Shogakukan's *Monthly Ikki* magazine but in May the Manga had gone on an indefinite hiatus and was ultimately cancelled. Takuya Mitomi illustrated a second Manga titled ***Jinrui wa Suitai Shimashita: Nonbirishita Hōkoku*** (人類は衰退しました のんびりした報告) which was serialized in *Monthly Ikki* from January till July of 2012 with a single tankōbon released in July 2012. 

Mitomi also illustrated ***Jinrui wa Suitai Shimashita: Nonbirishita Hōkoku 4-koma*** (人類は衰退しました　のんびりした4コマ), a 4-panel comic strip which began silealization in august 2012 issue of *Monthly Ikki*. a third Manga titled ***Jinrui wa Suitai Shimashita: Yōsei, Shimasu ka*** (人類は衰退しました ようせい、しますか), illustrated by Terae Kichijō was serialized in  Media Factory's *Monthly Comic Alive* from March 2012 with the first volume of it release in June 2012 and as of February 2013 there have been 3 Volumes released.

In 2012 and Anime adaptation aired in Japan between July and September directed by Seiji Kishi and produced by the Anime International Company A.S.T.A division with it being simulcast by Crunchyroll. Sentai Filmworks obtained licensed the series for subtitled Bluray/DVD release in North America in December 2013.
